repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Second Social Programmatic
            Development Policy Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Sector Programmatic
            Development Policy Credit Project covers the implementation
            and results of a series of two programmatic operations:
            Social Sectors Programmatic Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SSPSAC I) and Social Sector Programmatic Development Policy
            Credit II (SSPC II). The SSPSAC I has a satisfactory
            outcome, and is likely to be sustainable. Both the
            Bank's and Borrower's performance are
            satisfactory. The outcome of the SSPCII is moderately
            unsatisfactory and there is a significant risk to
            development outcome. The performance of the Bank and
            Borrower is moderately satisfactory. Among the lessons cited
            for both operations were the following: 1) the programmatic
            approach was a suitable instrument to help anchor policy in
            a period of growing uncertainty and instability; 2) using
            progress in a few selected Millennium Development Goals
            (MDGs) as a theme provided a well focused overall objective;
            3) clearer guidelines are needed for the role of supervision
            when a Development Policy Lending (DPL) program is
            interrupted; 4) the design of the monitoring system for this
            operation could have been improved; 5) a stronger alliance
            between the Ministry of Finance and line ministries and
            agencies is critical for meeting agreed benchmarks; and 6)
            the Bolivian context requires support for broad-based consensus-building.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Social Sectors Programmatic
            Structural Adjustment Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Social Sectors
            Programmatic Structural Adjustment Credit for Bolivia were
            as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. Findings and implications: the Social Sectors
            programmatic series, now entering its second phase,
            continues to be the right instrument to support
            Bolivia's social policies at this point in time. The
            support provided by the Social Sectors Programmatic
            Structural Adjustment Credit I (SSPSAC I) was selective, it
            did not focus on all the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs)
            but a few, related to education, health, and water and
            sanitation. The Bolivian political context has undergone
            several radical changes over the past year and the
            Government of Bolivia (GOB) is faced with significant
            pressures from different and opposing forces in society.

5040920.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Social Sectors Programmatic
            Structural Adjustment Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed Credit is aligned fully
            with the Bolivia Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) presented
            to the Board on January 8, 2004. The CAS clearly identified
            the role of this series of Social Sectors Programmatic
            Structural Adjustment Credits (SSPSACs) in supporting
            progress in the social sectors, highlighting that particular
            attention would be paid to reducing inequality in education,
            health and nutrition, and water and sanitation outcomes
            across municipalities, ethnic groups and income classes. As
            reflected in the CAS, if at subsequent stages of preparation
            Bolivia has made progress in formulating its revised Poverty
            Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP), the second and/or third
            SSPSACs in this series could be converted into a broader
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC). This series of
            SSPSACs have been prepared closely with other international
            donors. Germany (through KfW and GTZ) has actively
            participated with technical assistance and joint missions
            with the Bank in its preparation and has formally announced
            its interest in co-financing the first Credit in this series
            with Euros 8 million. Meetings with the donor community were
            held in La Paz to ensure coordination around the proposed
            social program and the areas to be supported by the SSPSACs,
            and seek synergism with other ongoing efforts. Various
            countries have contributed significantly with their
            experience and technical assistance in the design of
            specific components of this operation. Lastly, this series
            of SSPSACs has been closely linked to an overall
            intemational donor effort in Bolivia to support monitoring
            and evaluation of progress made to attain the Millenium
            Development Goals (MDGs).
